title: Fasting and Nutrition
content: Why women may have a harder time fasting, and tips for those who are struggling; Is there any place for fasting as part of a nutritional strategy in adolescents?; How do you foresee fasting as a mechanism for performance in athletes?; Are there any supplements Peter things are beneficial to be taking?

title: Learning and Health
content: Tips for learning and retaining large amounts of new information (and the best nutritional approach); Which tests are worth doing if you want to be proactive about your health?; Is it possible to obsess so much about your health that it becomes a negative stressor?

title: Performance vs. Longevity
content: What workout would Peter do inside a hotel room?; How does Peter’s training differ when optimizing for performance versus longevity?; How does taking testosterone and growth hormone affect performance versus longevity?

title: Fasting Tips from Peter
content: Peter suggests checking glucose levels to get some insight into why he energy might be so low. Peter says when you feel this crappy, it’s important to not push through. You also need MORE water than you think. When you fast you excrete sodium at a higher rate. Secondly, food has water in it so you need to compensate for that. Don’t cut caffeine for a long fast if you are a big caffeine person.

title: Fasting in Adolescents
content: There may be certain situations where it might make sense such as obese kids, T2 diabetes, NAFLD. But at the same time, one has to be very careful. Adolescents are still growing (anabolic mode). There is a critical window during which deprivation of food can be potentially harmful. I’ve certainly seen a subset of people who have eating disorders during adolescence and it sort of imprinted their endocrine system in a way that’s come back to haunt them as an adult.

title: Tips for learning and retaining large amounts of new information (and the best nutritional approach)
content: What is your preferred diet for consuming large amounts of information? Simple answer: Anything that is going to minimize swings in glucose. Is fasting helpful? Peter says it’s unclear. The literature about fasting and cognitive performance is not that great. However, there is tons of anecdotal stuff (e.g., more mental clarity). Peter personally has felt remarkably sharp while in ketosis. Exogenous ketones. Peter says taking a ketone ester could help (as it seems to have helped him in the past). Peter suggests that as something Apolo could try out. In summary: “If I were in that situation, I don’t think I would fast during that window necessarily. I’d probably do some time restriction and eat a really clean diet that, even if it wasn’t fully ketogenic, it would probably be relatively low carb.”

title: What workout would Peter do inside a hotel room?
content: First, would make sure to have a stability exercise. Dynamic neuromuscular stabilization (DNS) exercises. On your back, or front, or side working on core activation. Intra abdominal pressure (IAP). “Symmetric cylindrical activation”. There’s a whole bunch of exercises there, but Peter makes a hybrid one of those. Secondly, a single leg lunge. So the single leg step back (or step up) lunge. Or perhaps a single leg “get up” off a low surface. Finally, he’d to handstand push ups. Put legs up on a wall, but not in a “full stand” position (you don’t need to be under that much stress). Peter’s doing this as a scapular exercise (good way to train serratus strength and shoulder stabilizers)

title: What is Peter’s ultimate gorge meal?
content: Peter loves sushi but would find that hard to “gorge” on. Probably would be a multiple-course italian meal. E.g., salad, pasta, meat dish, gelato. Curry stir fry. “I can seem to eat it in infinite volumes probably because it feels so healthy.”

title: Fasting for Performance in Athletes
content: Peter thinks fasting is a powerful tool for athletes, especially for injury recovery and inflammation. He noticed a reduction in inflammation and little aches and pains just vanished. However, when fasting, his top-end endurance is lower, he needs more recovery time in between sets, and it hurts a lot more to push himself. Peter thinks most athletes are over-training in volume and intensity and under training and specificity. An alternative strategy for athletes is hypocaloric feeding with creatine supplementation.

title: What Drives Peter to Strive for Excellence?
content: Peter considers himself a very lazy person innately, but he is obsessed with knowing stuff. He loves learning and teaching, and it is really hard for him to let go of a question he doesn’t know the answer to. There is probably a whole bunch of neurotransmitters that are involved in the satisfaction he gets from learning something new.

title: mTOR and Longevity
content: Peter is excited about anything that involves mTOR, which is a potent nutrient sensing protein aggregate within cells. Transient inhibition of this nutrient sensing machinery seems to produce a really impressive longevity phenotype. The easiest way to demonstrate the longevity benefits of inhibiting mTOR is with the drug called rapamycin. Fasting is another way to transiently turn down mTOR, and more drugs are in development for mTOR inhibition. Peter calls it 'the most important target of a longevity strategy.'

title: Rapamycin
content: The first study unequivocally showed the power of the drug rapamycin in treating normal mice was published in 2009. That effect has been demonstrated repeatedly across multiple strains of other mice and all sorts of different animals. Peter takes rapamycin himself once per week, but he doesn't see anything noticeably improving in his blood work. Many patients, on the other hand, see huge improvements such as lipids getting better, their triglycerides going down, and their glycemic stuff getting better. Must be taken intermittently, doing it daily doesn't have the same positive benefits and comes with more negative side effects.

title: Trying New Interventions
content: Peter wants to see really convincing animal data and some sort of human clinical evidence of the manifestation before trying new interventions. He'd like to really understand the mechanistic reason this effect is happening and bracket his risk. He tries to reduce confounders when doing self-experimenting by making sure the conditions are consistent. We need better assays to measure nuanced cellular responses to drugs.

title: Developing assays to measure the effects of nutrition and exercise
content: I really wish we would spend a lot more time and resources developing the types of assays that could measure the more nuanced cellular responses of these types of drugs. We already have amazingly potent treatments (fasting, exercise, metformin, rapamycin, etc.) What we don’t have is tools to really measure how well they work on healthy people in terms of producing longevity. Why don’t we? The diagnostics business is a really bad business to be in. It would require creating a new business model. The business works around creating molecules, not creating tests to measure things like what fasting protocol is best, for example.

title: Nutrition and exercise as incredible drugs
content: The deeper I get into the science of longevity, the more I am absolutely convinced that nutrition and exercise … are such incredible drugs. They’re so ubiquitous. Like you can do them so often, you can spread that dose across so much.

title: Finding the balance between health obsession and negligence
content: Is it possible to obsess so much about your health that it becomes a negative stressor? How do people find the happy medium where they are not stressing about their health but also not being totally negligent? One can absolutely spend too much time obsessing over this stuff [to the point where it becomes an added stressor in their life].

title: Tests worth doing to be proactive about health
content: Peter is not particularly interested in measuring things for which he can’t do anything about it. There are a handful of genes that pose a risk for disease later in life that I know can’t be changed. But to know your APOE genotype is in fact useful. You can’t change it, but you can get insight into your risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Exercise plays an incredible role in maintaining hippocampal volume, maintaining blood flow to the brain, controlling metabolic circulating factors that play an important role in the preservation of cognition.

title: Tests recommended by Peter for proactive health
content: Lp(a) levels: Somewhere between 1-8 and 1-12 people have elevated Lp(a). It’s the leading cause of inherited risk for cardiovascular disease. APOE test: To know that you’re in a higher risk version I think should motivate you to work that much harder. That said, even the lowest risk category doesn’t mean you won’t get it.

title: Responsibility of liquid biopsy for cancer screening
content: Only about a year away from liquid biopsies really becoming commercially viable which is a blood test where it’s going to look for circulating DNA or RNA. It will tell you if you have circulating cancer cells including the cell of origin. So this comes with some responsibility: Imagine you’ve got a blood test and it came back and said you’ve got circulating breast cancer cells, but your mammogram is normal with no lump in your breast. What do you do with that information? Would you be able to do molecular imaging? Would you be able to start targeted therapies?

title: Continuous Glucose Monitoring
content: Peter would put a continuous glucose monitor on everybody for at least three months. It would be incredibly instructive for people to walk around and understand how their glucose levels change with respect to what they eat, how poorly they sleep, when they sleep poorly, and how much their cortisol levels go up, etc.

title: Supplements
content: Peter says about 80% of the population is probably very deficient in EPA and DHA. These are two very important omega-3 fatty acids that we get from fish. Data are reasonably compelling that having high levels of EPA and DHA in your tissue membranes is beneficial when supplemented to the right level.

title: Training for Longevity
content: Optimizing for longevity (i.e., being a kickass 90-year-old) compared to being the best at something (i.e., performance) changes how Peter does things. He does single arm isolated floor presses and uses a bamboo pole with big springy rubber things on the end and it’s hanging kettlebells off it. Maybe a total of 80 to 90 pounds. Given how unstable it is and how much it’s bouncing, it’s a far better exercise because it’s not putting a fraction of the stress on his joints and it’s forcing stabilizing muscles to do their work.

title: Testosterone and Growth Hormone
content: Testosterone is in some ways the easiest drug to give somebody because more is always better in terms of performance. You can’t have too much testosterone in your body if your goal is to do anything that requires strength or speed. And truthfully, despite all of the fear mongering around drugs, testosterone is a staggeringly safe drug. Growth hormone is probably a great example of how it’s almost always going to improve your performance, but Peter doesn’t think of it as a great tool for longevity.
